*div1 type="summary"* *p*Editorial by Austin in Texas Gazette, September 25, 1830. Friendly disposition of Government toward Texas. Need of judiciary reform and separation from Coahuila.*/p* */div1*
*div1 type="body"*
*p*Letters have been received by a *person_mentioned*gentleman */person_mentioned*in this *location_mentioned*place */location_mentioned*from *person_mentioned*persons high in office */person_mentioned*and in the confidence of the nation. Their letters express the most friendly and natural disposition towards this and all other *location_mentioned*colonies */location_mentioned*or *location_mentioned*settlements in Texas*/location_mentioned* that have been legally established. Great solicitude is manifested in these letters for the prosperity of this *location_mentioned*country*/location_mentioned*, and for its advancement. They say in positive terms, that none of the rumors which agitated public opinion as to *location_mentioned*Texas */location_mentioned**date_mentioned n="Spring-1830">last spring*/date_mentioned* had their origin from this *location_mentioned*colony*/location_mentioned*; neither has there ever been any unfavorable impression against it. These rumors, they say, originated from a great mass of *location_mentioned*newspaper */location_mentioned*and *location_mentioned*other publications*/location_mentioned* in the *location_mentioned*U. S of the north*/location_mentioned*—stating among other things, that swarms of *person_mentioned*adventurers */person_mentioned*and *person_mentioned*fugitives */person_mentioned*from justice, who could remain no longer in their *location_mentioned*country*/location_mentioned*, were about to overrun and occupy *location_mentioned*Texas*/location_mentioned*. Such an event would have been ruinous to the tranquility and prosperity of this *location_mentioned*country*/location_mentioned*, and therefore demanded the prompt attention of the government.*/p*
*p*It must be confessed that publications similar to that by "A revolutionary officer," and many others which contain nothing but base and infamous slanders were well calculated to ruin us, both in *location_mentioned*Mexico */location_mentioned*and in *location_mentioned*foreign countries*/location_mentioned*. There is cause to suspect that one of the great objects of these *person_mentioned*slanderous scribblers*/person_mentioned* was to stop the emigration from the *location_mentioned*U. S. of the north*/location_mentioned*, or from other *location_mentioned*foreign countries*/location_mentioned* to *location_mentioned*Texas*/location_mentioned*. . . . They appear to have acted on the principle to make *location_mentioned*Texas */location_mentioned*a part of the*location_mentioned* U. S. of the North*/location_mentioned*, or to keep it down and consign it for years to the *location_mentioned*wilderness */location_mentioned*and the occupancy of the *person_mentioned*Indians */person_mentioned*by damning its reputation so that no Honest, wealthy or civilized *person_mentioned*man*/person_mentioned*, would remove to it. . . .*/p*
*p*We have in former numbers of the *location_mentioned*Gazette */location_mentioned*stated that the cause, and the sole cause, of any and all the little bickerings and confusion that may have existed in *location_mentioned*Texas*/location_mentioned*, since *date_mentioned n="xx-xx-1821">1821*/date_mentioned*, have proceded from the want of a proper organization of the *person_mentioned*local government*/person_mentioned*, and especially of the *person_mentioned*judiciary*/person_mentioned*. In this respect a change is necessary, and is daily becoming more so. It has become a matter of serious doubt whether *location_mentioned*Texas */location_mentioned*will ever rise or prosper, so long as it is united with *location_mentioned*Coahuila*/location_mentioned*. The question of separating, with the view of forming a *person_mentioned*territorial government*/person_mentioned*, as a *location_mentioned*territory of this nation*/location_mentioned*, is beginning to occupy much of the public attention. This is a serious question, and merits the most calm and mature reflection.*/p*
*/div1*
